One of my first actual phones after the flip phone age, was the Sony Ericsson Xperia Play, which was a smartphone that was mostly intended to be used horizontally like this one‚Ä¶ And if you slid the back of the phone down, it would reveal what was essentially a PlayStation controller that was inside of your phoneüòÖ And then it popped out when you turned it horizontally and slid the back of it down. I was only about 10 or 11 at the time I think?? And it was the first (actual) smartphone that I‚Äôd bought myself.. It cost me just over ¬£400 (GBP) at the time I think? And it was amazing‚Ä¶ For about 3 months. As with me not even calling myself a casual mobile gamer.. the gimmick grew old very quickly hahaha!! I‚Äôd always wanted an iPhone, and I just simply couldn‚Äôt afford one at the time..

But 3 months or so after I bought the Xperia Play, my cousin (who is the kind of person who gets the latest iPhone every single time), he had just got the newest iPhone at the time. Which was the 4S.. And he had no idea that I‚Äôd just gotten this new Xperia Play.. But he always knew how much I had always wanted an iPhone. So when he got the iPhone 4S, he very kindly gave me his iPhone 4 for completely free‚Ä¶ Which didn‚Äôt even have Siri on itü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüòÇüòÇ But hey, I had finally got my dream phone.. The iPhone! Leaving my ¬£400+ 3 month old Xperia Play collecting dust in a drawer somewhereüôÉüòÇüòÇ It was definitely one of the more expensive purchases that I regret the most from when I was a kid hahahaha!!

But luckily, I‚Äôm the kind of guy that will get an expensive phone or tv or gaming console‚Ä¶ And use that for years and years until it either breaks, or it becomes embarrassingly outdated and is about to break purely just due to the materials falling apartüòÇ Like my biggest purchase before the Xperia Play, was when I bought myself a new (at the time of course) 32inch Samsung TV for my bedroom‚Ä¶ Which cost me ¬£320 (GBP) at the time! It isn‚Äôt 4K or anything like that, it‚Äôs not even a smart TV! And it‚Äôs about as thick as an old school phone booküòÖ And I still use it to this day to play my PS4 on, and it still works like a charmü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü§£ Although I am considering replacing it soon though.. Within the next year I think? But it‚Äôs not getting thrown out (like it probably should be doing at this pointü§£), it‚Äôs going to my 8 year old nieceü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è As she will be moving into her own room soon and she will need a TV in there, and I‚Äôll be moving into a bigger room at the same time. And I‚Äôll almost definitely need a bigger TV in there due to the size of my new bedroom compared to my current one, and as my TV still works like an absolute charm and I‚Äôve never had any issues with it at all, I‚Äôm going to let my niece have it for her new bedroom and then I‚Äôll just try to get myself a new one if I can doü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Also, which is probably painfully obvious at this point. Mine and my families financial situation is on its ass, and has been pretty much since the beginning‚Ä¶ So I/we can‚Äôt afford to be buying new tech every year or even every 2 years or anything like that.. Not even close!! We just simply use it until we can‚Äôt use it anymore.. And then replace it if possible afterwards!!

The Xperia Play was definitely a bad purchase as far as how much usage I actually got out of it to say that it was a ¬£400 + phone, which was all the money I had in the world at that time, so if I could go back in time I would have definitely saved my money.. The actual phone was a good gimmick, similar to what this one is like now‚Ä¶ But unfortunately that‚Äôs all that it was, a gimmick!!

Well I do play games more than just casually. I have an Xperia XZ Premium. Snapdragon 835, and it does everything i throw at it.
Yes there are sometimes frame drops (game dependent), but it can run everything.

Do I need this extremes this has? No.. absolutely not. Would I want trigger buttons? Yes, for sure. Most would want added buttons.

The phone is exciting and futuristic, but, I don't really need this much power on a phone. There is almost nothing in play store my phone can't run still, so until we get to a point that snapdragon 835 is ancient, and the phone can't run games smoothly, then I will get a new one.

And still, I think a flagship of that year, would be more than enough to slay any game play store has. Yes that phone might get warmer than a gaming phone, but who cares?
Personally, when my phone heats up during gaming I get excited. It's like I'm one with it at that moment.

So no, it's not for me. I'm glad it exists yes (like you), but I buy a phone, to get a phone.

When i look for phones for personal use, I don't really care for what its for.
I look for phones that perform well, for a long time, and do what you need it do ‚Äîand do it optimally.
I'm a modding enthusiast, and the more catered that the phone is toward the user, the better it is for my usage. Less heat on the battery means a longer lifespan for that battery, especially with phones nowadays where manufacturers laugh at the idea of removable batteries.
A phone that can perform well will last longer in terms of future-proofing. Chrome webpages will eventually eat more processing power, the internet will become more interactive and flashier, so a power and performance efficient device is really well worth it (compared to the garbage Apple spews into the market every year).

Lenovo could also give a HDMI dock and a bluetooth controller and this could legit be a mobile "console"! This hardware planning and execution is so well done, this makes me wish there was an open Android fork for this and future gaming focused devices - something that lets game developers squeeze more performance out of the hardware, and deliver even better visuals. That would really be something interesting, like what Nintendo Switch brought for console gaming.
Many of the indie games today - especially those for Switch - can run easily on Android or iOS. One main reason developers sometimes don't release their titles on phones is that most often it isn't worth porting with non-freemium revenue model on mobile app stores because sales are usually not good enough for paid games. If there was an "alternative" platform (both OS and App Store) that made porting/developing for worthwhile, we'd suddenly get a platform that's not locked to a single manufacturer like Nintendo, but something much bigger and open.

Yes I would consider buying and using a gaming phone for many reason
1.) Performance. I will love a phone with performance in mind. My samsung s9 clearly wasn't made to be used for game and thus kills the performance very early when it get warm
2.) Features. I will love features that will allow me to further pursuit a higher frame rate and graphics quality without the lost in performance and overheating
3.) A fan!!! I'm kinda tried on how I need to sit down to use a fan I got on a table when I want to casually play games like Genshin impact without me cooking my hands and/or having 10fps.

Apple: No charging port in our next iPhone

Lenovo: Sure, we will have 2

Edit: For the people in the replies, I think both companies are awesome, and no hate to either one of them! üòÄ
@Cole S You typed all of that to say a whole lot of nothing lmao

@Tom Stevens Don't know man. But atleast they didn't have to buy the brick separately. I'm okay having the slow charger since I always plug it in in the night.

In some of the european countries Apple had to include the adapter in the box since the laws of the country wouldn't allow sale without it, so I',m guessing it was possible. And plus, Iphone users will mostly buy the next iphone. This is surely not going to attract any android users who might be looking for a switch.

If I recall correctly, some android phones removed the brick too, but its available for free incase you want it with the box. That would've been a better way to handle this.
@Tom Stevens The screen thing was a joke ofc. You're lucky to use an e-sim. In many countries it's not supported yet, delaying the removal of this fairly large internal part.

@h4x0y I don't think they can technically sell a phone without a screen though. A phone isn't a phone without a screen, motherboard, processor, and battery. If they remove any of the things, they can't legally call the thing they're selling as a 'smartphone'. The SIM tray though, yeah, I don't care about that. Personally, I use an e-SIM, and so do most of my friends and relatives. The only people I know who do use a physical SIM are the ones who need two numbers.

@Kalpesh Patel Um, but afaik, most iPhone 8 or later users have a USB-C adapter too. Yes, I'm aware that while it didn't come with the fast-charging adapter in the box, pretty much every iPhone 8/X/XS/XR/11 users I know did indeed buy their own 18W adapter when they purchased their phone.

Correct me if I'm wrong though, but most of the above iPhone users worldwide bought the adapter separately. I mean, why wouldn't they? If they're already buying an at least $700 phone, they might as well shell out for an extra 20 bucks for the 20W brick and utilize one of the major features of their phone.

So consequently, most people who're upgrading to an iPhone 12 already have the 18/20W USB-C PD adapter, which means they don't need to buy another one.

Lenovo: Aight, we will use 2 cables and a big brick

I'm looking specifically for a gaming phone, but I don't want it to look like a gaming phone. I'm digging the direction that Asus is taking their ROG phones but I'm also really liking the form factor of this Lenovo. My ultimate wish would be to have some kind of Steam controller like functionality or even some Steam integration into the phone itself. Not really much of a mobile gamer but I'm not afraid to play my desktop games remotely through my phone. The problem with phone hardware is how proprietary it is at the moment. I'm loving the functionality and integrations of these gaming phones with shoulder buttons and "grip button" areas but if I were to put any other OS onto the phone I'm afraid all that functionality would be gone. On my desktop it's a bit less of a pain. I can dual boot into either Arch Linux or Windows 10 and have a fairly comparable experience on either OS without worrying about my desktop turning into a paper weight, while with a phone I'd be afraid of bricking it or losing out on a significant portion of the integrated hardware functionality if I were to switch operating systems.

So I might be insane, but I'm considering this or the ROG Phone 5 despite the fact that I don't play games on my phone. I mostly use it for communication, pictures [which I'm using a Pixel 2 XL and that's perfectly fine for me, and have a Nexus 6P that I use as a secondary camera and find it acceptable], researching things on the go, hotspot, navigation, and media consumption. But there are a few things that make me feel like one of the two might be great for me:

Battery: I'm using my phone all day, and GPS especially is a killer. The huge batteries on these gaming phones, as well as the insane fast charging, would make it easy to last a whole day without worry of running out of juice. The battery preservation features, such as being able to control how fast the battery charges and to delay the FULL charge so it's not sitting at full overnight is great. Plus I might even leave the phone unplugged overnight and do a fast charge in the morning. But these features will probably make sure the battery is still working pretty well after 4-5 years, even if it is degraded -- 50% of these massive batteries is still insane, and I can imagine them doing at least that well in a few years.

CPU and RAM: The insane power of these things will probably be most noticeable in a few years when they're old. My Pixel 2 XL is almost 4 years old, and it shows -- sometimes it just chugs when I try to do something fairly simple, like open the camera and take a picture. It can't handle doing a GPS application, a podcast, and taking a picture at once -- they all poop out. Often this is due to running out of RAM. But with 18GB... I can't imagine that being a problem, even 5 years from now.

Storage: Lots of storage, and fast storage at that.

The front-facing speakers and active cooling, as well as the fact that the hot parts are away from the batteries, also is great, because heat from the other components accelerates battery degradation, so that's a huge plus for me.

The only way I would buy a "gaming phone" is if it comes from a ridiculously reliable company with amazing and solid build quality that will last for several years at the minimum - and of course I think it pretty much HAS to be an LCD display on account of the burn-in issues you may face with AMOLED or OLED screens when  you have static things like button icons on the screen for long periods of time - which a gaming phone would. Next, they can't skimp on the camera - if they could put out a camera system that does video and photography on the level of the S21 Ultra, for example, has a very reliable build quality, LCD screen, and can pretty much crush any game you put on it? Then yes, I absolutely would buy one. BUT since these other things are more of an afterthought, for me, personally, it's a no-go because I am someone who wants to just buy one phone - just one - and not have to worry about upgrading for YEARS - 3 to 5 at minimum. I don't ever want to do the yearly update dance. Hence why I still use an iPhone from 2014.

Hey Marques! Just a comment about the battery configurations. The fast charging is actually a result of the 2 batteries being in series. as an ex-hardcore average playing playery guy dude with a gaming phone (rog phone 3), stay away from gaming phones. if you need to game on the go, play a non-resource hog game that any phone can handle. you do not need to play bannerlord or doom eternal on a train to pass the time. you can play games on your computer at home using steam link, in which case it's streaming tech and your specs are wasted.

carrying around a huge, heavy brick is a gigantic, literal pain in the arse, especially since 98% of the time YOU ARE NOT PLAYING A GAME ON YOUR PHONE. touch controls are the worst, if you want performance, you have to use attachments like a keyboard and mouse, or maybe a controller if the game doesn't require perfect precision (or can't in the first place because it's a shit port). bluetooth is also another point of latency by the way. no matter how hardcore you are, there is absolutely no reason to buy a gaming phone.

if you're a casual then you don't care. if you're average then you care a little, but you shouldn't care enough. if you're hardcore, then ask yourself.. would you buy a gaming laptop? if you said 'yes' you're not hardcore, you're just average with a lot of money. if you're an aspiring pro, or an actual pro, stop playing your main game on the go, you're only learning bad habits.

i recommend getting a small, light phone with a thicc battery.

This phone would help heaps with call of duty, fps and genshin. Problem is they are capactive triggers. You will Tire your fingers out by not letting your fingers rest on the edges especially in longer gaming sessions. I know this as I actually am a hardcore mobile gamer and was using Rog phone. This is why physical triggers are still better aka black shark series. Edit: To answer the question at the end, yes I've considered a gaming phone. I was in the market for a new phone since I was using the iPhone 5; and I do always have at least a full page of games on my phone so at that time the Razer phone had just came out. To me the Razer phone looks better than any other phone to this day, I love the box design and all. However, I ended up going with the Note 9. Games I was playing at the time weren't too crazy (like Bloons TD6 which WOULD overheat my iphone in later stages), but I cared more about having a better gaming experience on my phone than the ability to take top-notch photos. Luckily with the Note 9 I kinda get the best of both and as a note-taker the pen feature is sick. No regrets personally, but if I was wealthy I'd definitely have a gaming phone as my dedicated mobile gaming machine.

I live in South Africa which is not very major in the tech world but has alot of diehard gamers. Problem is most of the cool gaming stuff does not get made here and needs to get shipped over from America, Europe etc.
I am 13 and a half rn and growing up never really got into gaming. I had a PS3 since I was 6 and never made a PSN account. Then I got a samsung galaxy s4 when I was 9. I never played anything online coz I never had wifi. I used to buy data if I wanted to do something online, I must add that Data prices in SA are very expensive compared to everywhere else tho my parents had phone contracts with data but I never bothered about it. So then lockdown happened and I was playing on my PS3 the few games I had. One day the s4 just stopped working ( this was in June 2020 ) midway of SA lockdown. I started playing on my PS3 a bit more daily as I had nothing else to do. My parents did not take well to this lmao. I had loads of time so I decided to complete the 2 games I never had finished back then. These games were Need For Speed: Most Wanted 2011 and Need For Speed: Rivals. I successfully did it and was bored again. I thought about it and remembered my mother had a samsung galaxy note 4 that had a faulty battery. I spent some money on a battery for it and it was good as new. Shortly after this my dad got a 4G SIM contract. I then had access constantly to YT and online features in games. I played a bit and watched more vids about online games like pubg, csgo etc. I knew about fortnite for awhile but never liked it or wanted to play it. One day on May 11 2020 I downloaded PUBG and COD:M I played both and deleted PUBG mobile instantly coz it was trash in my opinion but CODM on the other hand captured me till date. I play it everyday and started buying the battle pass since Season 9 last year. I saw some gaming phones online and wanted them all. I always had a liking to stuff for long periods of time but none actually stuck with me 100% when I was 4 - 7 I was obsessed with dinosaurs and the Jurassic franchise and 8 - 12 it was tech that I loved especially Samsungs smartphones. I still like Jurassic world but that's off topic. Yeah so I wanted a gaming phone, my favourites were the ROG Phone 3, redmagic 5G and S and the Black Shark 3 but due to a combination of insufficient funds and not being able to purchase them in my country Led to me not getting them last year but this year I have my eye on the ROG Phone 5 Ultimate, Redmagic 6 Pro and this bad boy, the Lenovo Legion Duel 2. I cannot purchase them in country either but I entered a competition to win either the red magic 6 or 6 pro. If there is a way to get it please tell me.

Yes, I would love to buy this... Or ROG Phone 5... Because the thing is when you are playing a competitive PvP games like pubgm or cod etc at the highest level (ACE or Conquerer in pubg or Legendary in COD) the fight gets so intense that normal flagships phones just can't keep up, I mean literally you can feel the lag (might be network issues sometimes but this happens) and believe me it's so frustrating when that happens and it happens almost every time... Most flagship phones work fine for the first half hour or an hour but after that the perf drops are visible and you can feel them... PvE games like asphalt, etc are easily playable even on normal flagships, you don't need a gaming phone for that, surely the gameplay will be hella Smooth and Satisfying AF in these 120hz disp etc but... THERE ARE NO STAKES IN SUCH GAMES AND YOU DON'T ACTUALLY NEED THE BITS OF ADVANTAGES THAT THESE DEVICES PROVIDE... I have a suggestion for marques... use PvP games for testing, bring in or collab with some hardcore gamers (who plays at the top in those games) so you can literally push the device to the limits to see difference... Just a suggestion but if possible... It would be very informative for us hardcore gamers, also it would be very cool to watch that video... I specifically try to buy gaming phones as my daily driver. The reason being, the tech is totally boosted. For example, i currently own a ROG Phone 3. Apart from the led backlight that everyone asks, the boosted cellular reception, extra wifi antenna, a worry-free huge battery, extremely fluid display, loud speakers, reverse charging, dual charging ports, etc etc, does make the smartphone using case scenarios much better and tailored as compared to traditional smartphones. I can charge it once and ignore the battery percentage all day, use it like a powerbank if needed, hear it ringing from my room upstairs, have it connected to my car's Audio system while its parked in the garage and ensure that i get wifi coverage on my entire plot while other phones struggle. All of this while having a different design and a powerful SD865+. And yeahhh, i do play pubg, crazy taxi, 8 pool, forza street, twd, bb racing and the occasional angry birds 2...

my gripe with this type of phone is that for the price, it is coming very close to being able to buy a whole pc with peripherals. personally i would simply wait until i've got enough money for an entire pc system and game that way. but also if people ARE buying this phone for the purpose of just gaming why not just buy a console at the price point? It's really cool how companies couldn't reproduce Apple's huge taptic engine, so Lenovo literally just made a symmetrical phone and put in two vibration motors to compensate. Like, it's not saying Apple is superior or anything. They put in smaller batteries and relatively smaller camera modules, so they have space for haptic engines so big. So Lenovo just put in two smaller haptic engines so that it takes less space per half of the phone. This is so easy to think of now that it's been done, but almost feels genius ngl.

Calling any phone a gaming phone when they all have the same cpus and gpus vs the non-gaming phone is just dumb. Yes it has some stuff tailored made for gaming but ultimately they are all just gimmicks. The touch "buttons" are gimmicks. The fan while being nice is a gimmick. Not to mention it gimps the phone on protection from the elements. And nearly all flagship phones have high refresh rates, its just slightly faster than most. Sure the touch rates are in a league of its own but again its currently a gimmick.

The only positive thing i will give this is that it has active cooling to allow the phone to avoid thermal throttling. But other than that it has the same gpu and cpu as the s21. Theres nothing special about its cpu and gpu that separates it from non-gaming. Its like trying to call a laptop with a pentium and no dedicated gpu a gaming laptop. Its just misleading as fuck.

Lets see them use a sd888 alongside whatever the switch pro/2/whatever has for its gpu. You do that and yeah i will hand it to you for calling it a gaming phone. But yeah just a sd888, high pulling rate and touch buttons with active cooling and rgb do not make a gaming phone. a lot of this is just superficial. Get a powerful mobile gpu inside and then we can talk. Something like what samsung is doing with teaming up with amd. That will make for a gaming phone.

I play Call Of Duty Mobile and I wish I had a phone with a Snapdragon 8xx series SoC, because my Samsung A50 is throttling HARD. Low quality, high frame rate, after a few games I start losing some battles just because there's too much lagging and freezes while ADSing or quick movement. And it's worse if the phone is plugged in, gets really toasty, barely charging.  It's a problem for mobile 3D gaming, lower end chips just have really weak graphics. And I don't want a $600-1300 phone, because why do I need to pay for 5 cameras and stupid glass on the back... 6.5" AMOLED, 6 Gigs of RAM,  4500 mAh battery with working under load fast charging, ONE decent camera and clean software - that would be enough for me as a mobile gamer JUST if the graphics on the SoC were reasonable. I had my phone for almost 2 years now, Samsung just launched a new A series with a 720G Snapdragon for the A52 and A72, even added water resistance, and I wish it was enough for my use, but I don't think so... And they cost around $300, and where I'm from it's already solid money, but to step up the game (literally and figuratively) I'd have to look at something like S20 FE which is twice the money! And the funny thing is, I know, mobile gaming - first world problems, but good luck trying to get yourself a PC or a console these days. And for some of us gaming is a way to cope with everyday struggles. So yeah, gaming phones! The more, the better! Peace.

When people think of "mobile games," they think things like Candy Crush, Angry Birds, PvsZ, PubG, Asphalt, etc., or they think of freemium and gatcha games. But mobile gaming is much, MUCH more than that (especially once you look beyond the free games).

There are a ton of ports and remasters on mobile--most of the older Final Fantasies, many of Sega's classic games (all of the 2-D sonics, Altered Beast, even Crazy Taxi), and games like A Bard's Tale, The Banner Saga, and so many more are on Mobile. Many companies make full, original games meant for mobile--Downwell, 80 Days, Sky (from the makers of Journey), Smash Hit, Eternium, EvoLand, Ragnarok M Online (a full-fledged mobile 3D MMO), and many more that are not freemium or gatcha, and are ridiculously fun. Hell, even gatcha games have changed immensely, with the likes of Genshin Impact, Fire Emblem: Heroes, FF Brave Exvius, and Another Eden (from the writer of Chrono Trigger) really pushing the boundaries of the genre on mobile. And on top of all of that...there are emulators for all the classic games that you own but want to play on the go.

Because of all of that, I do not in any way look down on mobile gaming anymore. It's not as powerful as PC, but the right phone can really show its worth if someone is looking to play games on the go at any time. I would buy an Asus ROG Phone 5, just because they've had so many iterations of it to get it the best it can be, they know what gamers want, and it does other things immensely well (not going to lie, the big double-speakers are a huge positive). This phone does appear great, though, with a lot of quality-of-life things for gamers that even the ROG Phone doesn't have. But as an all-around, and considering what else I'd want my phone to do (gaming, music, phone calls, photos, etc.), I think the ROG Phone still has it beat by a bit.

I don't understand spending big dollars on a phone. Maybe 3D gamers could use a powerful phone the way a desktop gamers can use a crazy desktop, but both are an indulgence. Most people browse the web, text, email, and run a few relatively simple apps. A $150 Moto G can do it all, and you can get a premium experience from a $300-400 phone, where you can get close to flagship performance and features in the areas that matter to you. Do people really get 2-4x the phone when they spend 2-4x the money? I suspect that many people buy their phones on contract, where the costs are hidden and don't seem so high. I wonder how the market would change if people had to pay up front for fancy things that amount to tech jewelry.

Hands down, yes I only have interest in a gaming phone. I've been saving up for a Rog Phone 5 Ultimate in particular, but this is easily a second contender. The only advantage Rog phone has over this is accessories, Rog phone has a ton of incredible accessories for gamers.

The games i play vary, it's mostly genshin impact these days. With the regular implementation of controller support and cross-play, as well as streaming services like Game Pass Cloud, having a gaming phone just increases my ability to game wherever, whenever. There's nothing quite like playing Halo at a park where you get good phone signal. Plus tons of games lately have been high quality, and emulators have seen a lot of progress over the past few years on mobile.

Honestly though, I wouldn't be surprised if Xbox enters the phone market with a "Series M" phone line. One of the biggest advantages this could have is the Xbox Wireless standard, reducing input lag even more on phones for Xbox specific controllers, improving the performance of streaming platforms. Gaming phones are growing and I'm happy to feel like I can enjoy handheld gaming again.

The next revolutionary thing would be phones with mind control or maybe holographic displays/glasses.

Lets try to answer Marques ' question. I usually play every day for 3 hours. In the last month my phone, a Xiaomi Redmi Note 5, no longer supported that use. I decided to switch phones and considered two $ 600 options. The gaming option was the Red Magic 6 coming out this week. The other, more traditional option was a Samsung Galaxy S20 FE 5G. Two weeks ago I bought the Samsung. My decision was based on the aesthetics of the phone (I am not a fan of RGB), the software updates (Nubia does not have a good reputation about it), and the possibility of being able to buy a new Samsung in the future using their deals like the "trade in ". Also the reviews of the S20 on this channel and the award for best phone of 2020 influenced me. For now I think the S20 FE has met my expectations. A gamer, in addition to improving his experience, wants to have better results. The Samsung has made it. Now I have better CODM scores and numbers, so I'm happy. There are no more crashes, no overheating and the battery is enough to play the three hours a day. I just want to add that is kind of sad that Chinese products are being banned. That political issue also affected my final decision and I felt like I was being part of a monopoly market.

This is the only thing that can be called the GAMING phone. This thing has it all, I'm really impressed. For me, I prefer PC for a lot of reasons and it's not as expensive as you might think (even when my PC is at least twice as much as my phone and I own a S20 Ultra lol) since a flagship phone is already the cost of a very capable PC, but not being portable though... Laptops are more expensive, and can't do as much as an actual phone, and aren't even that small.

The thing that really gets me away for mobile gaming is battery life and heat in the device. This phone looks like it would definitely change that. It's powerful enough for emulation and maximum gaming possible in a phone, for traveling and moving on, this looks like the best deal overall. An ironical thing is that the only game I have time to play now is Genshin Impact, that I play the most on the PC for the reasons I already said but... If I had this phone, I would play way more on my phone and on the go, definitely.

I would not buy this phone because I really need a good camera (thinking of actually switching to an iPhone because I hate this nonsense 108mp sensor, hopefully Note 21 or S22 will have a better camera experience with small objects AND an expansion slot). But if I had to play some Genshin Impact for a long time, or even COD Mobile, PUBG or even emulate whatever I want, not to mention a cloud game service would have a good experience too, specially with Razer Kishi, I would definitely buy this phone.

I'd happily consider a gaming phone if I'm not limited by the compromises. I am not a mobile gamer; not even a casual one. However, I am into emulations and retro gaming. I grew up playing Sega Genesis and N64 games. Most people do not understand the reason behind having 16-18 GB of RAM and an overclocked chipset, which is definitely an overkill for most mobile games. However, the story is different in the emulation scene. Having a better chipset with more RAM always helps. Being able to play any game up to Wii U (Maybe Switch in the near future) on the go is a dream for me. As smartphones get more powerful, more emulations will be possible, and having those gamer-oriented features like rumbles and multiple dedicated buttons would actually help.

I'm not much of a mobile gamer, but I occasionally play some games like genshin impact and a few time killer mobile games, and I've been looking into a gaming phone for my next one not necessarily for those games, but because the "gaming" features actually sound great for daily use. Like when my current s20 gets old, the battery life is likely to degrade due to overheating and fast charging, and performance will degrade due to having just enough speed for today, but having a phone with overkill cooling, 2 giant batteries, and overkill specs means I will have performance to spare in the future.

I'm not a mobile gamer but I imagine younger generations are more geared towards that and picture this would definitely be a sort of pay to win way of competing on mobile games online. If they just made a Switch a bit smaller and put a phone it in that would be my daily driver. Some of the specs on this thing just seem to vanity. Not sure how many titles are really going to harness the most power from this but it's pretty cool. If I was going to get a gaming phone I would pick this over the N-Gage. The built in streaming is a pretty cool feature though I'd be worried about the gears on the motorized camera wearing out after a while and the camera quality might not be that good. I do like the idea of an all-in-one streaming device in such a small form factor. Would be better if it was matte black.

To answer the question at the end I am that guy. I play 6 finger claw on a iPad Pro 2018 (Octopus lookin ass) But I play games like cod mobile competitively, I used to play fortnite mobile and before that critical ops (csgo on mobile). I would definitely consider this phone if I get into t1 teams (which is unlikely) because they do indeed force you to play on a phone but other than that I'll stick to my iPad. The touch sample rate and performance is better but the refresh rate is almost the same and the screen size is much bigger on the iPad which is important to me because I play with 6 fingers. I would definitely consider a gaming tablet if it ever came out however but right now the tablet that runs best in games is the iPad pro 2020 (Yes I know the tabs7 is better on paper but trust me that is just on paper and does not translate to performance in games) . Final thoughts I would probably not get a gaming phone specifically because of the screen size even though there are clear performance benefits to a phone like that (and also the 4:3 resolution on iPad vs 16:9 resolution on phones which makes seeing edges of the screen better in fps games on phones) because of the way that I play games (6 finger claw PogU).

To anyone wondering, the big push for "Gamer" phones is likely heavily influenced by the Asian market. Notice how Western companies are hardly investing in gaming phones (other than maybe Razer). To your question at the end:
A big question for me wound be, how well can I plug it into a monitor/TV (with a HDMI dongle) and pull out a Xbox controller and play something on an emulator or some mobile games.
Because this thing seems to have the power to also do things like that and with things like Game Pass Ultimate (xCloud) this could be an alternative for having a console at all.
If someone has to decide if he wants a Xbox or a cool/good phone and does not have the money for both... this could be the device he/she needs or wants.

Yes, most android phones for years now support HDMI out via the USB-C port. Then you bluetooth a PS4 or Xbox controller and you're good. This setup itself doesn't require that much processing power, so the limiting factor will be what type of game you want to play. Pretty nice if you travel a lot (Trucker, frequent hotel stays) because, honestly, nobody's bringing a console with them; too bulky.

After being spoiled by a 1440p@120hz display with my Oneplus 8 Pro, 1080p just feels like a step backwards for me, I have yet to hit a single bump with 12 gigs of ram pushing every single game and upscaling the quality of everything to QHD as well üòÖ I've been sketchy about Lenovo as a company for many years after seeing so many returns and negative remarks about their laptops and tablets during my employment at Walmart selling electronics, I'd have never considered them a legitimate competitor till your review of this phone, I may be happy with my superior viewing experience, however I see the practicality in many of the extremely unique adaptations to this device that will likely be copied by heavier loyalty based companies to bring a more immersive experience to gamers in future models, I love the placement of all the cameras, pop-up included, just needs to be higher quality and some attention from a maker that will check all the boxes, the idea of dual haptics and a cooling fan, are a gamers dream, beautiful ideas, I think the double wire charge is nothing to get stoked about though, in a year or less that will be nothing by comparison to wireless charge capabilities, and shortly after that over the air wireless charge will be more mainstream, efficient, and affordable, starting with boxes that charge devices in between them, eventually to overhead ceiling units that charge from above, eventually even working it's way to units over streets to keeping you charged on the road, that eventually includes the cars themselves üòú

@AlisterCountel thank you for the explanation, but I still have my doubts.. A few points actually, from you explanation
1. Who would put a 6.9inch phone on their back pocket, say if someone did(and cringe) it would fell really uncomfortable
2. I can't see a scenario where anyone would front bend a their phone especially at the middle as he did(i can see it cracking tho)
3. If any gamers were to rage hold their phone to the point of breaking, he clearly isn't cut out for gaming (talking from my experience from gaming to top rank in several game<not to bragüòÜ>)

@Pickle Pie The bend is intended to mimic a few situations, really anything where the phone receives stress that would push differentially between the outside and the middle. One common example is people who have place their phone vertically in their back pocket for a moment, then sit down. We tend to start sitting at an angle, so it will be stressed at the top and bottom while the middle receives the opposite force.

Alternatively, if you have it in a front pocket, falling into an edge (such as a small concrete wall near a building) creates a similar stress.

For the last example, an angry GAMER GRIP‚Ñ¢ would do this to some extent.

Realistically it‚Äôs not a common situation, but it‚Äôs a valid concern. The ROG at least died slowly (i.e it might survive a small amount of force like this), this phone seemed to just snap instantly instead of cracking or anything.
Jerry did snapped it like a toast, from the side antenna lines but not from the middle portion.

Would I buy a phone for gaming specifically? No, but it appears that these gaming phones have a lot of what I am looking for in a phone, but realistically, they are overkill. I am still rockin' my LG G7, and I really appreciate my phone. Now that LG is dead, I have to look elsewhere for my wish list items: excellent speaker (preferably dual speakers), water and dust resistance, wireless charging (fast if possible), decent battery. I think everything else is just bonus stuff. Notice I didn't say I needed a 120hz refresh rate screen or anything above 1080 resolution. I just don't game or do anything that requires that much luxury specs. If I get them, that is a bonus. I look at these gaming phones specifically because they have that dual speaker and they usually have a decent battery, but the cost of the phone is at least double what I want to pay for my next phone, and honestly, it is probably a bit too big for me. Yes, I have huge hands, but I don't want something in my pocket that is so big that it doesn't sit properly when I sit.

In reality there aren‚Äôt mobile games that are high demanding that require a special gaming phone for.
But have to admit this is the most impressive gaming phone ever made, mainly because of the fact that they were not trying to hide the fact that it‚Äôs supposed to be a gaming phone

For me, I don't game on my phone. I am and believe ill always stick with a console gaming experience. I mean gaming on a TV with surround sound is a better experience than going out and buying a $1000 phone. A 4K TV can be bought for around $250, and an awesome console can be gotten for around $500. If you get the Switch that only $300. So I think that's more fun for me than looking at a small screen. On a side note, I use the switch and Xbox series X and the Playstation 4  and I enjoy playing Legend of Zelda, Halo, and other games on the TV. I'm not saying I'm well off or not trying to brag (I worked hard to get all of that), I just made the post for people considering if they want to buy a "gaming phone." If you just buy a Switch and a $250 dollar 4K TV, that still gives you $450 dollars to get a really good phone. Then you can play more intense games on a 50 or 60 inch TV.

I'm an intensive gamer with 2/16 GB and 3500 mAh battery
But if i ever get enough i would definitely consider buying a gaming smartphone!

to your question at the end:
nah.. I'm a PC gamer.. but I didn't have a PC for a long time and actually streamed to twitch from my phone for a while (xiaomi mi 9t)

it worked surprisingly well.. the mic sound wasn't bad at all and the performance was more than enough for the type of games I like to play (stardew valley, don't starve etc)..
the things that were really annoying were:
- to hold the phone in my hands for long periods of time.. but I just put it on a little self made stand and there are ways to connect a controller to your phone as well..
- that my front cam was on the side and either down or up depending on how the phone was oriented.. that combined with the phone usually being at a lower angle than your face makes for an extremely ugly angle that I definitely didn't want to use as my web cam during streaming.. there also wasn't a streaming app that you could even use your front cam as a webcam with.. but there was a way to work around that and use a google gaming function inside a different streaming app..
- and lastly there wasn't a good all around streaming app that I could find that seemed official and safe enough but also offered similar functions to what you can have on PC with OBS.. overlays, alerts, showing chat and all that..
and the biggest downside was that none of the apps had the permission to use the system sound.. so I could never use headphones and had to capture the game audio as well as background music and my voice all through my phone speakers.. I ended up playing the background music from my laptop, so I could balance game sound and music better.. and since the phone only had a speaker on one side I connected a bluetooth speaker that I positioned directly behind the phone so the game sound would be in stereo because it was being captured through the microphones on both sides evenly..
it was all very complicated but I got it to work somehow
it looks like some of those things were thought of while making this phone and it seems to have the streaming ability already built in which looks really cool! if it also has ways to implement alerts and stuff or connect to streamlabs or something it could make for an awesome phone to stream off of, especially if the permission thing isn't an issue and you can actually stream the game sound directly.. I think games like pubg mobile are pretty successful on twitch too.. could be great!

Just wanted to make a interesting point, that u might not know. At this point after snapdragon 865 or even snapdragon 765, the problem with android phone is not in their raw power, but games like Pubg are specially optimised for apple users but they are not optimised for androids, no matter what, games like Pubg always laggs in android in intense circles, but not in apple phones. It was never about that 18 gb ram or snapdragon 888 after a certain point ( even snapdragon 765 or 870) raw power doesnt matter it is about whether the app is specially optimised for that phone. You may be suprised but games like pubg would run much smother in IPhone 11 (not even pro) than in any other android phone. It is simply because of optimisation. Yes i phones battery sucks but it doesnt even matter, if u research enough, every Pubg pro ( almost everyone even in fnatic who is sponsered by oneplus) players always used Apple phones in competitive tournaments ( unless that tourney was sponsored by a phone company).

100%. if i could afford it. unfortunately I can get a last years phone which does the job. on a deal. if i buy on launch its maybe 30% more. however half of that is my including data, mins and txts. the phone contract is often cheaper than a sim only when bought over black Friday.  ie i was paying 20 a month for unlimited everything sim only. a Blackfriday deal the previous year netted me a s10 and the same deal for 26 a month. 6 x24 = 144. so im paying spread out. 144 gbp for my s10 that I got 18 months ago. in this day and age I can't justify buying a gaming phone for a lump sum plus pay the 20 a month. even if it wasn't on a deal contract bundles are by far the most efficient way to get a phone. and until network providers start bundling in all the phones in deals. its  a no go. its easy to say phones a, b and c  are 700 800 900 respectively.  but then the network provider says oh pay 1000 over 2 years for a. b is 1100 but c ? oh boy thats not available thats 900 upfront. maybe 700 with a trade in. and its not 300 over 24 months its now 600 . and thats the problem.  with pushing these devices out . the best versions don't sell enough and so they aren't available in a bundle. yes it maybe 20% more upfront but it will cost me 80% more. networks only seem to make mega deals with samsung or (prior lg) or apple. and at one point Huawei. personally id kill for a gaming device.  i always wonder why my phone even has a camera or the like. best game recently is probably frostborn.  shout out to JCF maybe gaming devices should sponsor him XD as hes pro mobile gaming .

I am constantly looking at the gaming phones industry not specifically for games, but for innovation. ASUS ROG 2 is the best example in that regard. The package it offered comparing the rest was 1 year ahead of the competition. The same happened with the Razer Phone. It's 120hz screen with amazing speakers was something that made me look with interest at the future of phones. Another great example, and probably the best overall package at it's time, is Samsung Note 9 with it's liquid cooling system, and the minimalist gaming app built in the phone. Unfortunately for this Lenovo, I believe this is a bit too much...unlike the phones mentioned by me, this one goes to far and as you have said, it is a console in a phone package. Hopefully it will get a good fanbase so they can improve on their ideas and release a 2nd version that is more refined!
